Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, was born on April 24, 1985, at St. Mary's Hospital in London, England. He is the younger son of Charles, Prince of Wales, and the late Diana, Princess of Wales. Harry's full name is Henry Charles Albert David, and he was christened with the baptismal name "Henry" at St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.

Prince Harry was educated at Eton College and later trained at the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst, where he earned the Queen's Golden Sword of Honour. He served two tours of duty with the British Army in Afghanistan, including a six-month deployment as an Apache helicopter pilot.

In 2014, Prince Harry began working with various charitable organizations, focusing on conservation, veterans' welfare, and mental health. He is patron of over 20 charities, including the HALO Trust, which works to remove landmines and UXO from conflict zones.

In 2018, Prince Harry married American actress Meghan Markle at St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle. The couple has one son, Archie Mountbatten-Windsor, born on May 6, 2019. Prince Harry and his family are currently based in North America, where they are pursuing a more private life.

Prince Harry has also written a memoir, "The Spare," which was published in 2023 to critical acclaim. In it, he shares his personal struggles and insights, including his experiences with mental health and his family's challenges in the public eye.

Throughout his life, Prince Harry has demonstrated a commitment to service and a desire to make a positive impact on the world. He continues to be a beloved and respected member of the British royal family.

Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, was born on October 12, 1985, in Kensington Palace, London, to Charles, Prince of Wales, and the late Diana, Princess of Wales. He is the younger brother of Prince William, Duke of Cambridge.

Prince Harry spent his childhood at Kensington Palace and Highgrove House, the family's country estate. He was educated at Eton College, where he excelled in sports, particularly polo. After completing his A-levels, he attended the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst, where he trained as an Army officer.

In 2007, Prince Harry began his military career, serving two tours of duty in Afghanistan with the Blues and Royals regiment. He was known for his bravery and humility during his time in service, earning the respect of his comrades.

In 2011, Prince Harry co-founded Sentebale, a charity that supports vulnerable children in Lesotho, Botswana, and Malawi. He has since become a vocal advocate for mental health awareness, LGBTQ+ rights, and conservation efforts.

In 2018, Prince Harry married American actress Meghan Markle, now the Duchess of Sussex, at St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle. The couple has two children, Archie Mountbatten-Windsor (born 2019) and Lilibet Mountbatten-Windsor (born 2021).

Prince Harry has been involved in various philanthropic initiatives, including supporting conservation projects in Africa and promoting educational programs for underprivileged children. In 2020, he and his family stepped back from their senior royal duties to pursue a more private life, splitting their time between North America and the United Kingdom.

Prince Harry is known for his charismatic personality, sense of humor, and commitment to making a positive impact on the world.

My wife, Meghan, and I have also launched our own charitable endeavors, including the Archewell Foundation, which focuses on education, women's empowerment, and the environment.

Despite the many demands of royal life, I've always prioritized my mental health and well-being, knowing that taking care of oneself is essential to living a happy, fulfilling life.
